text: <@U0H7SU4E8|ajit.bohra> has joined the channel
RXJava  have some own operator link a map and flatmap operator but don't understand difference between them cause i can do same thing in both operator.
map transforms your output into some object, flatmap transforms it into an observable
You mean flatmap have to use when more than one asynchronous operation ?
yeah that sounds right
or you want to feed the output of one observable into another one

Looking into this operator : <http://reactivex.io/documentation/operators.html#alphabetical>

I used to only this two operator . :disappointed:

<@U0H8T67QB|pedroloureiro> has joined the channel
<@U0H8X0T5E|pedrohyvo> has joined the channel

what is the difference between onSaveInstanceState()
and setRetainInstance() ?
So I have a fragment that hits an endpoint in onViewCreated()
when i rotate the device and change the orientation
onViewCreated() will get called again
i want to prevent that unnecessary endpoint call
so here are the three scenarios
1) rotation happens before the endpoint gets called
2) rotation happens during the endpoint call
3) rotation happens after the endpoint call
how do you handle all 3 of those scenarios ?
`setRetainInstance` causes the Fragment object to be retained on config changes instead of destroying it and making another instance... so your member variables and such will be retained
I just check if I already retrieved data in onStart, if not, I retrieve it i.e. `void onViewCreated() { if (data == null) requestData(); }`
that would be in my presenters, not my fragments, but same idea
do i need to call onSaveInstanceState()
not if you're using setRetainInstance
save the state in outState
gotcha
so how do i check `data`
I think onSaveInstanceState might be what you do if you don't retain the fragment but I'm not sure
I just always retain them haha
is there getRetainInstance
retainInstance is a flag in the fragment
if it's true, the fragment is not destroyed when the activity is recreated
so in onCreate for your fragment just do setRetainInstance(true)
yes i am doing that
then how do i get the `data`
is that saved in some kind of global variable
are you caching the data you retrieve from your service somewhere?
that's what `data` represents
at the moment im not
hmm
how would you recommend caching that data
using something like <http://Realm.io|Realm.io> ?
depends what it is, if it's not a lot of data you can just use a member variable in the fragment itself
okay
is there some kind of rule of thumb around this
if the data is a certain number of objects
then it should not be just a member variable
but persisted in some other fashion (file, sharedpreferences, contentprovider, orm solution)
hmm not sure if there's a rule really
you just have to profile how much memory is being allocated on that screen, if it crashes low memory devices then it's too much :stuck_out_tongue:
gotcha
thanks
np
